page.title: 01Holwick and Newbiggin
page.content: Here the turbulent river Tees tumbles over cascades and thrusts through rocky gorges. North of the river lies Newbiggin. Once a busy leadmining and smelting community but now consisting merely of a group of farms and cottages. Those belonging to the Raby Estates are traditionally white washed. To the south nestles Holwick, a scattering of sheltered farms on ridges of well drained glacial moraine dwarfed by the dramatic steep faulted whinstone cliffs of Holwick Scars. Above the crags stretch vast grouse moors. The only road to the village passes remnants of the natural forests of Teesdale and ends at Holwick Hall, a shooting lodge on the Strathmore Estates. As well as sheep grouse are economically important on the moors and tenants are obliged to provide beaters during the shooting season.
